citations.narrative:
During the inspection, one adult beagle “4571542” got part of its foot stuck between the slats in the cage flooring and
began vocalizing. Facility staff promptly freed the dog’s foot from where it was stuck. Per a facility representative, this has
been seen before with the beagles.
Flooring that allows any part of a dog’s foot to become trapped can cause injury. Primary enclosures must have floors that
are constructed in a manner that protects the dogs’ feet and legs from injury, and that, if of mesh or slatted construction,
do not allow the dogs’ feet to pass through any openings in the floor.
To be corrected by 7/19/2023.

The facility is using caging for beagles that does not meet minimum space requirements. The facility uses these cages to
separate dogs for feeding as well as for study related activities. Per a facility representative, dogs can be in these cages
from 30 minutes to a few hours. Eight adult beagles were seen in these cages during the inspection. One of these cages
measures approximately 21” by 28” which equates to 4.08 square feet. The adult beagle inside the cage measures 24”
which requires 6.25 square feet of space to meet minimum standards.
Failure to meet the required minimum amount of floor space can lead to unnecessary animal discomfort and distress.
Each dog must be housed in a primary enclosure meeting the minimum amount of floor space as required by the Animal
Welfare Act.
To be corrected from this day (7/17/2023) forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
